--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Karl Lewin <lewinke67@y...> wrote:
> To further clarify:
> 
> A new connection only gets a new innovation number if
> it connects two previously unconnected nodes.
> 
> A new node only gets a new node number if it splits a
> connection that hasn't previously been split.
> 
> Does this mean a split of a connection a->b always
> gets the same node number for the intermediate node,
> or can a->b be split multiple times and generate many
> nodes?
> 

The answer is that it depends on your implementation.  There are at 
least three ways to implement it.  In the latter 2 cases, a "record 
of innovations" is kept.  (My version of NEAT, and I think all 
others that I know of have the capability to keep such a record)
This record is a list of "things that were added."  So for example, 
it will say "a new link was added between nodes 3 and 7 and given 
innovation number 12."  Then, any time another new link is added, 
NEAT can look back through the record and see if it's already been 
added, and then if so give it the same number.  Anyway, here are the 
3 types of implementation:

1.  Don't have NEAT keep any record of previous innovations at all.  
In that case, splitting the same link multiple times will always 
lead to new nodes.

2.  Have NEAT keep a record of innovations, but clear that record 
after each generation.  In that case, the same innovation occurring 
in the same generation will get the same historical marking, but in 
the next generation the same innovation (e.g. connecting the same 
two nodes) would get a different marking.

3.  Have NEAT keep a record of innovations forever.  In that case, 
the same innovation *always* gets the same number for the entire run.

The FAQ question I cited earlier talks about the issues involved in 
choosing how to do it, but the short answer is that it's a judgment 
call, and there is no data to suggest one should strongly prefer one 
option over the other.  You may have opinions about which is most 
elegant/biologically plausible/conservative, and those will guide 
your choice.

ken
